title: Home reverted back to lender after foreclosure sale. Can I get home back to sell, I have equity. Thought I was safe cause ch. 13
question: Home in foreclosure,sold,reverted back to lender.I thought I was protected cause I filed ch.13 1 day before sale. Bank saw I filed 4 ch.13 in 1yr (all dismissed) said there was no stay, I thought there was. We need more time, we want to get home back to sell to make$. Non judicial, California. Original lender was resource lenders then sold to countrywide then to bac then to green tree. Recorders office only shows resource lenders then bac then green tree.
answers: Once the lender sells the property at a foreclosure sale, title reverts to the lender. At that point, the legal owner of the property becomes the lender, and title to the property passes to the lender, The owners of the property cannot file a Chapter 13 petition, or even file an adversary proceeding in an existing Chapter 13 case to reclaim the home, because there is no ownership interest for the bankruptcy court to protect. This is a different situation than a repossession of an automobile, which can be reclaimed from the creditor in a Chapter 13 case. You have lost your home for good, unfortunately. Bankruptcy filings are not DIY projects.

I write separately to address your foreclosure questions.

Transfers of a promissory note secured by a deed of trust are common, and no document is required to be recorded to evidence the transfer in California. What is relevant in a deed of trust is who the trustee of record is, not the beneficiary. (the beneficiary in a deed of trust is the bank or the person loaning the money.) The sale would only be void if the designated trustee or their agent did not conduct the sale.

As stated by my colleague since you had more than 2 prior bankruptcies within the year there was no automatic stay without a specific judicial order. The lender had every right to continue with the foreclosure. At this point you can look into a chapter 7 to discharge any remaining debts you have if you have not filed within 8 years. I'm in Bakersfield and can try to help you with any specific issues you may have but this sounds its past the point of fixing.

Unfortunately, if you have more than 2 prior cases within one year of the present case, there is no automatic stay until you file a motion to impose the stay. Therefore, if the sale was the day after you filed the (fifth?) case, you were not protected. Sadly, any one of those prior cases could have saved you if you had made them work out.

As for the servicers issue you are alluding to at the end of your question, you would need to have the documents reviewed by an attorney. If there is any chance at all, you need to seek out an attorney now because you are more than likely out of time.
